repnme.cdata!:
Tanzania - Country results profile :
            Sustaining and sharing economic growth

abstracts.cdata!:
This country results profile focuses on
            sustainable reform and economic growth in Tanzania. For the
            last decade, Tanzania has sustained high economic growth
            driven by structural reforms and improvements in economic
            performance and service delivery. Growth in Gross Domestic
            Product (GDP) has averaged between 5 and 7 percent a year
            since 2000. Access to primary education has increased
            dramatically, along with solid increases in net enrollment
            rates. Under-five child mortality has declined by more than
            a third since 2000. To assist Tanzania in meeting its
            development goals, International Development Association
            (IDU) will continue to actively coordinate with partners and
            participate in the joint development dialogue with the
            government. Going forward, the lending program will largely
            focus on the infrastructure and human development sectors.

repnme.cdata!:
Tanzania - Accountability, Transparency and
            Integrity Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Accountability,
            Transparency and Integrity Project (ATIP) for Tanzania were
            as follows: outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory; risk to
            development outcome was substantial; Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory; and borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned includes: the
            benefits and potential trade-offs associated with the aid
            delivery modalities need full consideration at the outset.
            The Bank's configuration of technical and financial
            support provided with the ATIP was informed by two major
            approaches: (i) Sector-Wide Approach (SWAp) approach to
            reforms, and (ii) the pooling of efforts, management,
            finances and oversight through the mechanism of common
            basket funds. The combining of sectors in an omnibus
            'umbrella project' plus the multiplicity of
            implementation agencies pose additional implementation
            challenges and increase transaction costs downstream.
            Available commentaries and lessons learned through previous
            sectoral works need to be carefully reviewed at design
            stage, to better understand the feasibility of the
            interventions and avoid over-ambitious targets. The presence
            of top-level leadership with executive capacity and
            strategic focus should be tested rather than too readily
            assumed, as their absence has detrimental effects at
            implementation stage. The constructive impulse to mobilize
            additional financing behind the government reform drive led
            to assumptions as to how 'ready to run' was the
            project design. Procedural and budgeting problems should not
            be underrated. Another particularly troublesome aspect of
            project management related to work planning in the context
            of mainstreaming and integration with Medium Term
            Expenditure Framework (MTEF). The choice to embed the
            specific conditionality of the Memorandum of Understanding
            (MoU) in the project design is highly questionable, as its
            costs far outweigh its potential benefits. The process of
            restructuring does not need to await the MTR but should be
            conducted as soon as there are signals that the DO may not
            be achieved and/or the IP has the prospect of being
            unsatisfactory. As referred to above, the attenuated
            consultative process to restructuring may have been
            inevitable. Defining and managing a robust approach to
            'change management' is essential when dealing with
            complex institutional reforms, and can help to maximize
            returns at implementation stage. Given the complex and
            difficult nature of cross sectoral public sector reforms,
            such a diverse and extended sector nationally, a robust
            'change management approach' was required to
            galvanize participating actors around the efforts for
            reform. The nexus of benefits to identified groups from the
            reforms needs to be established in all cases. Funding of
            non-state actors can be time-intensive and requires careful
            planning, with good information, clear criteria to guide the
            selection process and hands-on monitoring. This is necessary
            to ensure that activities are well supervised and
            strategically linked.

repnme.cdata!:
Tanzania - Accountability, Transparency,
            and Integrity Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
This project paper seeks the approval of
            management to introduce the following changes in the
            Tanzania - Accountability, Transparency and Integrity
            Project (ATIP) and any accompanying amendments to the
            project's legal documents: (i) changing the
            subcomponents and activities under component one on
            strengthening legal and judicial reform of the project to
            ensure effective use of the credit for its remaining
            duration; (ii) refining the project Results Monitoring
            Framework (RMF) to ensure results are appropriately
            captured; and (iii) re-allocation of the credit for
            sub-components under component three of the project. The
            changes will not affect the Project Development Objective
            (PDO). They are intended to ensure effective utilization of
            the credit to achieve the PDO.

repnme.cdata!:
Tanzania - Accountability, Transparency,
            and Integrity Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project will contribute to improved
            access to judicial and legal services and in the accountable
            and transparent use of public financial resources. This will
            be achieved by improving the skills and systems to deliver
            judicial/legal services and public financial management, and
            strengthening the capacity of oversight and watchdog
            institutions (OWIs) to perform their role. The program has
            four components: 1) strengthening the legal and judicial
            system; 2) enhancing public financial accountability; 3)
            strengthening oversight and watchdog institutions; and, 4)
            project coordination. To strengthen the legal and judicial
            system, this first component consist of six sub-components
            that will a) establish a harmonized national legal framework
            by amending key legislation, streamlining processes, and
            improving capacity for legal research, towards drafting the
            law reform. Also included are improvements to the legal
            environment for enhanced social justice, safety, and
            economic development, focusing on accessible justice by the
            poor and disadvantaged. Support will be provided to
            strengthen research capacity, and studies on a national
            legal framework. Moreover, improved governance and
            administrative justice will be supported, specifically
            within legal and judicial institutions, by enhancing
            transparency in the administration of justice through
            relevant interventions. To this end, improved skills and
            knowledge for legal professionals will be fostered through
            quality legal training, improved practical training skills
            for law students, and improved capacity on continuing
            education programs. An improved service delivery capacity in
            key legal institutions will entail the provision of
            organizational and support services, enhanced competence and
            integrity personnel, and an improved working environment
            (this includes infrastructure and civil works for office
            facilities). The second component will enhance public
            financial accountability, through improved capacity at the
            Ministry of Finance, so as to achieve sound macroeconomic
            and fiscal management, and, public financial management will
            be improved at ministries and agencies to improved resources
            on decision-making and accountability. The third component
            will strengthen oversight and watchdog institutions,
            particularly regarding crosscutting reforms, i.e.,
            generating high quality information on government
            performance and outcomes, focused on improving the ethical
            environment. Finally, the fourth component will support
            project coordination, i.e., monitoring and evaluation
            activities, support concerning institutional structures, and
            to information, communication, and education activities.

Tanzania - Accountability, Transparency, and
